summary:
Raised in a middle-sized Spanish city by a family very fond of travelling, I developed a drive towards intercultural encounters. At the age of 18, I moved on my own to The Netherlands to complete my BA in International Studies at Leiden University. 

I am enthusiastic about social inclusion, community building, and cultural diversity. I have a good working background in examining topics of international politics, history, and culture from a mixed-methods methodological approach.

I believe that to solve global challenges, it is paramount to first think local and bridge the gap between the public, policymakers, researchers, and local communities all around the world. I strongly believe that understanding each other's perspectives and needs is what brings about positive change.

Thus I am looking for working experiences in the sectors of communications, press, advocacy, marketing, funding, or research.

skills: ['Human Rights', 'International Criminal Law', 'International Humanitarian Law', 'Transitional Justice', 'Criminal Law', 'International Law', 'Rule Of Law', 'Public International Law', 'International Human Rights', 'International Relations', 'International Organizations', 'War Crimes', 'Human Rights Research', 'NGOs', 'Research', 'Politics', 'Public Policy', 'European Union', 'Civil Society', 'Democracy']
summary: I am an Assistant Professor in International History at Utrecht University, and a Visiting Research Fellow at the Department of War Studies, King's College London. I am a historian and a genocide scholar, and my work is on irregular armed groups, genocide and mass violence and transitional justice, especially criminal accountability. Before coming to The Hague in 2009, I spent three years in Sarajevo, where I worked as a researcher and analyst at the Special Department for War Crimes at the Office of the Prosecutor. I designed and taught an MA course on perpetrators and genocide prevention at Stockton University in the United States. My first book titled ‚ÄúSerbian Paramilitaries and the Breakup of Yugoslavia: State Connections and Patterns of Violence‚Äù came out in September 2022 with Routledge‚Äôs Contemporary Security Studies series. This research was based on archives at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) in The Hague. I am also one of three editors of the new CEU Press series ‚ÄúPerpetrators of Organized Violence: Eastern, Central and South-Eastern Europe‚Äù.

Turning my passion into professional experience, I am a Global Affairs Intern at The Ocean Cleanup. In parallel, as a Researcher at the Platform for Peace and Humanity, I publish Articles and Policy Recommendations on South-East Europe and the Black Sea Region. 

I currently pursue an M.Sc. in Political Science at Leiden University (specialization: Nationalism, Ethnic Conflict, and Development), while I also hold an LL.B. from the University of Athens, and a Minor in Sociology from the American College of Greece (Stavros Niarchos Foundation Scholar).

summary:
Warm heart for social projects. 
Experience with governmental organisations, politics, and business community. 
Politically sensitive. 

After receiving the International Studies degree, I enrolled in the MSc World Politics and International Relations at the University of Pavia (Italy). This master served to broaden and deepen my international focus, integrated further with courses on diplomacy, migration, integration, law, gender issues, international relations, and social sciences. Furthermore, the wide range of electives allowed me to pursue new fields of interest, as well as to continue my language studies initiated at BAIS. 

I look back at my studies fondly, appreciating the general knowledge of (geo)politics, economics, and inter-cultural awareness the degree has given me, as well as the irreplaceable experience of going abroad to explore ‚Äì and study in ‚Äì China, Taiwan, and Italy. Both my Bachelor and my Master have encouraged my critical and analytical thinking, and have equipped me with research, social, and writing skills, but most important of all, an open mind and tireless enthusiasm.

While working at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, I worked closely with diplomatic missions and international organisations. I also took my first steps in (international) event organisation - including the multi-day Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES) in the Hague. 

At Gemeente Hoeksche Waard I started further developing my knowledge of project-development. 

In the middle of the Ukraine-crisis, I started at Gemeente Nissewaard, and managed to turn the lovely chaos into a well-oiled structurally-sound shelter. 
I shouldered responsibility for everything including the refugee-locations and the Ukrainian refugees. From getting the locations ready for people during the crisis organisation, to keeping several locations with around 300 refugees running safely.

I look back fondly, and extraordinary pride, on the enormous responsibilities I have carried and what I have been able to establish so far in my carreer!

Currently working at Gemeente Midden-Delfland in the physical domain at the Location Development department.

summary:
I am an historian of the United States, with particular interests in gender and masculinity, the history of social movements, as well as cultural and intellectual history, a strong grounding in US foreign policy, and prior professional experience in international development and poverty reduction. I teach and supervise theses at UvA in the Netherlands and love this aspect of my work.

‚Ä®‚Ä®‚Ä¢ My book, The Machine Has a Soul: American Sympathy with Italian Fascism, was published by Princeton University Press in January 2021. 
‚Ä¢ Teaching classes in: American history; civil rights; social and cultural history; new approaches to US foreign policy; democracy in America; the history of populism and the white working class; MA thesis preparation course.   
‚Ä¢ Supervising BA and MA theses in American studies.
‚Ä®‚Ä®‚Ä¢ Earned PhD in US History (Georgetown), MA in International Relations, International Economics and American Foreign Policy (Johns Hopkins SAIS), MA in Human Rights and Democratization (EUIC), BA in Modern History (Oxford). ‚Ä®
‚Ä®‚Ä¢  Conducted archival research in English, Italian, and French.
‚Ä®‚Ä¢  Researched and published op-eds, articles and book chapters for academic and policy audiences on: the New Deal and democracy; the threats of fascism in the United States; American foreign policy in WW2; the American presidency and memory; urban-rural transitions and poverty reduction; recovery from conflict in Mindanao, Philippines; moving out of poverty in India; democracy and development; American responses to genocide.¬†‚Ä®
‚Ä¢  Worked for the World Bank Poverty Reduction Group (2005-2010)
‚Ä¢  Consulted the Government of Ghana on developing scaled-up investment strategy.¬†
‚Ä¢  Wrote speeches for parliamentarians at international conferences and for World Bank principals.

name: Catherine Yuk-ping Lo
position 1: Assistant Professor of International Relations and Global Health
skills: ['International Relations', 'International Politics', 'Research', 'University Teaching', 'Qualitative Research', 'Security Studies', 'Global Health Governance', 'Health Security', 'HIV/AIDS', 'Higher Education', 'Teaching', 'Lecturing', 'Social Sciences', 'Public Policy', 'Politics', 'Academic Writing']
summary:
Catherine is specializing in international relations and global health. Her current research interests include the politics of HIV/AIDS in China and India, infectious disease responses, antimicrobial resistance (AMR), global health diplomacy, and also global governance. She is the author of HIV/AIDS in China and India: Governing Health Security (Palgrave Macmillan 2015). Her book has been awarded the 2017 International Studies Association (ISA) Global Health Section Book Prize. 

She teaches extensively on topics of international relations, security studies, comparative politics, and global health, such as Chinese international relations and foreign policy, China and India in global governance, international affairs of the Asia-Pacific, and infectious diseases and global public health, at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels. 

She has supervised bachelor‚Äôs theses on international relations and security-related topics, such as Sino-Dutch relations, the Chinese Belt and Road Initiatives, South China Sea disputes, Huawei 5G Technology in Europe, and Chinese aid in Africa. She has likewise supervised masters‚Äô theses on global health governance, such as AMR in Europe, together with COVID-19 responses in China, Europe, and the United States.

She can be reached at catherine.lo@maastrichtuniversity.nl

summary: My professional life began at the Ethiopian Ministry of Foreign Affairs where I served in two Directorate Generals - African Affairs and Protocol. In African Affairs I was a desk officer for ten North, Central, and West African countries. My experience in the international politics of Africa is complemented by my academic career. I studied Political Science and International Relations at undergraduate and graduate levels and completed my Ph.D. studies in 2019 at the International Institute of Social Studies (ISS) in The Hague. With extensive teaching and supervision experience, I have the skills to supervise and motivate research at undergrad and graduate levels. My research skill is strengthened by reviewing papers for scientific journals and publishing in them as well as extensive field research in Ethiopia and archival research in the Nordic Africa Institute and the University of Cape Town. My job and research interests focuses on (East)Africa political economy, democratization and development, and elite/oligarchy studies as well as diplomatic and business relations of Ethiopia with the rest of the world.

summary:
Studying Political Science & International Relations at Erasmus University College, I have adapted an interdisciplinary line of thinking and realized no field acts in isolation. Having taken courses at EUC ranging from behavioral economics to courses discussing the Frankfurter Schule, I have become well-versed in making new disciplines part of my own. Furthermore, I recognize the value they hold on their own and in an interdisciplinary discussion. Political decisions have direct or indirect effects on economic, social, and environmental aspects of life and through having taken a holistic approach I aim to be able to analyze the direct and indirect consequences on the aforementioned elements. In addition, at EUC I have developed further academic interests in the development of the African Union, Chinese sociopolitical involvement in Africa, the growing presence of international terrorist networks, and the relationship between food scarcity and conflict. I aim to complete my postgraduate studies in the field of conflict resolution, focusing on sustainable peace solutions and the rebuilding of countries through a developmental perspective. 

I have a fond interest in learning but also in the various ways in which knowledge is acquired. Outside of EUC, I am involved with Stichting Landmerk; a foundation that aims to enrich the Dutch high school and university landscape, offering lessons in rhetoric, philosophy, politics, literature, and law. I have been invited into their ‚Äúteacher in training trajectory‚Äù, which is a weekly, 7-hour convention in which we discuss, amongst other topics, didactics. This topic continues to fascinate me and has allowed me to also take the perspective of the professor in my current classes. By furthering my capabilities and understanding within the field of philosophy, I am not just furthering my understanding of the interplay between philosophy and politics but also my ability to effectively and critically reason.

I am an incredibly motivated student as illustrated by my current full-time study while having been the Chairman of the Erasmus University College Student Association (EUCSA), doing internships, and being a teacher-in-training at Stichting Landmerk and aim to not only yield a productive output out of my courses but position myself within the academic discourse and actively engage with the material to make it my own.

summary:
I am an internationally oriented storyteller with ambitions to develop myself further as a researcher, a journalist, and an author. Through a combination of creativity and analysis, I continuously try to improve my understanding of the world and bring others along on that journey. At the moment, I am putting my passions for research and writing to use as a doctoral student at the University of Helsinki. My dissertation project concerns the role of music in United States boarding schools for Native American children in the 19th and 20th centuries.

During my time as a student of American Studies and History at Radboud University in Nijmegen, I became acquainted with the different ways of conveying a story, from academic publications and journalistic articles to literature and photography. I switch effortlessly between Dutch and English, and time spent living in the United States has made me culturally versatile as well. In addition, my role as a member of various (editorial) boards and committees has taught me to work in a team, exercise leadership, and above all to be open to new challenges.

Internationalization, education, and policy-making are topics that fascinate me. I have a true passion for the field of education and see education as a great tool of soft diplomacy; to change the world and collaborate between nations on a different level. After obtaining my graduate degrees abroad, I worked several years in the field of secondary and higher education in Colombia, Mexico, and the Netherlands.  In the classroom I always focused on teaching my students to become global citizens with 21st century skills and preparing them for education abroad, making sure they have the right soft skills to be successful. 

As an international professional, I can easily work inter-culturally. I have a true passion for international education. I have also been actively involved in the organization of international university fairs in Central and North America, as in the Caribbean. I am an active member of network that connects international college counsellors at high schools in Latin America, in which we bring higher education opportunities closer to our students in the region, share knowledge and best practices, and ensure that all schools have access to the same resources and university contacts. This has led to increased opportunities worldwide, for all more students in this region. 

Currently, I work as Fieldwork Coordinator at the BSc Global Studies program at Maastricht University. Here I continue to connect higher education globally, looking for ways to connect engaged global citizens and collaborate internationally via education.

summary:
"We study the past to understand the present; we understand the present to guide the future."

Quotes like these sometimes tend to sound like oversimplified platitudes. Also, I won‚Äôt add ‚Äòclairvoyancy‚Äô as one of my LinkedIn professional skills. However, sayings like these have always inspired me to move forward in my endeavours and form a guiding principle throughout my (academic) career.

I am a passionate and ambitious master‚Äôs student with a special interest in International Relations. Especially the European Union, Human-Rights and civil society related subjects peak my interest. I love to delve into a regions culture to try and grasp an understanding of its current political and social dynamics. Factors that can potentially determine a regions bright future.

As a History of IR student, I have built a considerable frame of reference about the differences and historical origins of international identities. I know how to quickly analyse, contextualise current political events and get to the essence of complicated texts and policies to set up research.

Additionally, I have a total of four years of experience standing in front of full classes as a teacher in higher education. Aside from learning about the merits and flaws of education systems and its influence on citizenship. I developed essential public speaking, communication and management skills. I greatly benefit from these in academia, whether it concerns giving a comprehensive talk, leading or participating in a group assignment.

As recently as June 2021, I finished my traineeship at the SDG House/TRGConsultancy. Together with a multidisciplinary team we developed a didactically sound teaching module which focuses on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and world citizenship. In this programme I propelled my understanding of the international agreements regarding a more sustainable, peaceful, collective future even further.

Moreover, I want to build a stronger expertise regarding the multiple perspectives on international politics and conflicts. Therefore, you can imagine why I chose to do my second masters‚Äô ‚ÄòConflict Resolution in Divided Societies‚Äô at King‚Äôs College London. I want to to take a deep-dive in how I can potentially help and bridge the divide.


I strive for a career in International Relations where I can delve into relevant socio-political problems and make a difference. I want to surround myself with experts from all different backgrounds, disciplinaries and walks of life so that I can challenge myself every single day.

I can‚Äôt wait to find out what the future holds!

summary:
I am a highly motivated and ambitious Research Master in European Studies at Maastricht University, passionate about history, the European Union, international relations, and political decision-making. My master's thesis will explore the role of women in the European Parliament during the European Economic Community, focusing on "The ‚Äòmissing‚Äô women of European Integration".

As part of my two-year degree, I am currently interning with Dr. Aline Sierp (Maastricht University) on a research paper about norm-building in memory studies. I am also a research intern with the Contested Histories Project by Euroclio, where I write reports on controversial monuments and street names. My experience with these internships is helping me to develop my analytical and research skills.

In addition to my studies, I am the head of the Marketing department of the European Careers Association Maastricht (ECA). As the marketing team leader, I work closely with my colleagues to implement our marketing strategy and promote ECA. I am also a German teacher at Belingual Maastricht, which allows me to share my knowledge and expertise with others.

During my Bachelor's degree in political science and social and economic history, I participated in Erasmus and spent time at Tartu University, Estonia. This experience sparked my passion for history and the European idea. I was also an active member of Model United Nations, participating as an organizer, delegate, or chair in more than 10 conferences during my Bachelor's. In my last year, I discovered a passion for Marketing, which I was able to explore through an internship with the Unicorn Factory. I was also part of the Model United Nations Society G√∂ttingen, and in 2019, I organized the annual G√∂MUN conferences as deputy secretary-general. This role required me to fundraise ‚Ç¨5000 from NATO, manage the conference logistics, and ensure academic standards were met.

In my free time, I enjoy attending MUN conferences, travelling, and reading various books, such as fantasy, romance, biographies, and LGBTQ+ literature. I am also part of the UM Pride Book Club and JEF. Spending quality time with my family and friends is also important to me.

Overall, my diverse experiences and passion for European Studies make me a valuable addition to any organization or team.
